p: A candidate antimalarial agent should elicit parasite suppression of 30% or greater [ 39]. Hence, the extract at all doses tested was found to possess a promising chemosuppression effect and found to be active in counteracting the malaria parasite. Furthermore, if the antimalarial activity of a compound displayed a percent growth inhibition of ≥50% at a dose of 500-250, 250-100, and ≤100 mg/kg/day, the literature grades it as moderate, good, and very good, respectively [ 16, 39– 41]. Therefore, the fruit of C. frutescens possesses a very good antimalarial activity.
